Osawatomie, Aug. 28, 1880. Dear Sister Mary
I received your good and full letter Wednesday evening. The Bryonia powders to not seem to do me as much good as the pellets. It was the same with some Lycopodium powders you sent some time ago. It did not occur to me that the little paper marked "one dose" was a sample dose. As I felt dizzy and bad, I swallowed it. And perhaps I am not taking right doses. I feel a little better since I have been taking them. My stomach is weak. I can not eat but little. I have no pain, except a very little occasionally about my head, a dull heavy feeling. I feel pretty well when lying down. In that position I can read. But when I get up I am weak, either sitting or standing, and feel a little nauseus.

I think it is owing to malaria attacking my weak point - the stomach. Perhaps if I had not got the Bryonia I should be suffering from fever by this time. I have not had a movement of the bowels for a day or two. If you could send me a few Bryonia pellets, or if you think the powders the best another sample dose, I would be very much obliged. Aconite and carbo seemed to help my stomach when sour but I am nearly out of carbo. I am sorry I cannot write more. I have received three letters from John Eddie. The last two I have not answered, because I have been having all I can do in my state of health, and so have delayed. When do you expect him back in N.Y.? Your affectionate brother John R Everett.

Osawatomie, Aug 4, 1881. Dear Sister Mary
I was very glad to get your good affectionate letter. I do not undertake now to write you a letter for I have no time. But this is on a matter of business. I vomited after dinner one day last week, and since then I have been troubled with unpleasant symptoms of a return of the same. I think it arises from malaria and perhaps overeating. I have been taking Aconite and Carbo alternatively. I am now just out of Carbo, and would be very much obliged if you would send me some. I am also taking Bayonia, but all rather irregularly, for I forget. I am going to try Lycopodium in place of Carbo. I also take Lactopeptine after every meal. I did take it in water,

two teaspoonsful of California wine, with better result, I think. I just write this because I have a chance to send to the mail. It is just after breakfast. I ought to be washing my dishes so I can help milk. We are haying - prairie hay is cut late. There are 23 cows for two of us to milk. And I have got to work over butter while it is cool. I only get 13 1/2 cents for butter - most of the summer only 11, and that is a cent or two above the market here. I hope to get more soon. So I am barely able to keep along with my outgoes with all the help I must hire. Forgive the hurried and imperfect letter. I am sorry I have not written to you before. From your loving brother John R Everett

Osawatomie Dec. 31, 1883. Dear Sister Mary
Have you heard lately from our friends in Steuben. It is six days (four days last Saturday when I had my last mail,) since I have had any letter. I think they must be snowed up, and the heavy fall of snow you speak of on Christmas might have affected them some days previously. I received yours written Christmas between 4 & 5 Saturday afternoon and began taking the Lycopodium. Finished three papers in the night last night with no effect, and began taking the Sulphur with no effect as yet. With the exception of weakness feel very well. Have had for a couple of days a slight pain on the left side behind under or below the lower long rib.l I think I was threatened at first with pneumonia. I had a sore place in my right lung - could not take a full breath without coughing. I thought Bryonia helped it. Finally my cough became very loose, and it seemed all to come away in phlegm. I feel best before my breakfast in the morning, after I eat I want to lie down. After about three or later I am better again, and sit up most of the time till bed time. Last night I slept well till about 1/2 past three. I eat two

more than that quantity of graham or oatmeal mush. So you see I ought to be gaining, and I am a little besides a little apple sauce or cherries or peaches. I have read a good deal. I have been reading Creasy's Fifteen Decisive Battles of the world's history, beginning with Marathon, and ending with the surrender of Burgoyne and Waterloo. Also Schiller's Thirty Years War. I am now reading Dean Stanley's Sermons on Special Occasions. As they were some of them preached before the Royal Family, they are a little flunkeyish in places, but with that exception they are suggestive and quickening, not demanding your assent everywhere, and (an excellent reccommendation) without apparently trying to do so, quicken one's desire to read the Bible. He takes up the Book of Esther, remarks on the entire absence of the name of God, and makes this novel inference, that a man may be living a useful and a Christian life without making any parade of his religion. -- I have sent for some light reading now (a little too light a diet fear only reinforced in some way) "The Spy" and "Green Mountain Boys" (revolutionary tales) and the First volume of Hans Christian Anderson's stories in bound in cloth and all for 90 cents from John B. Alden & Co 18 Vesey [?] St New York. I must stop now with love from your brother John R. Everett

Osawatomie, Jan. 3, 1884. Dear Sister Mary
I do not know that I will have any chance of sending this to the mail to-day, but I will write a line. I think I am gaining a little strength, but very slowly. I drank a little milk last evening, and it interfered with my sleep. I find I can not take any thing after dinner. I have nearly finished the Lycopodium. I have about 4 papers left. I will take nearly a cup full of water and only take one teaspoonful at a time to make them last longer I have read no directions, either as to the amount of water or the dose I would like to try it a little longer. The effect has not been marked, but I used to think it did one good. Would you be kind enough to send me more? We have had two very cold days - the first snow of this month. New years day was as tedious a day as we ever have - snowing and blowing with the thermometer from 3 to 5 degrees [he uses the degree sign] above zero. To day it is pretty still and mild. With much love your brother John R Everett Please to write me how your health is. I hope your visit is doing you good, and that you are enjoying yourself.

Osawatomie, Jan. 12, 1884. Dear Sister Mary
I am your debtor for 2 letters since I have written to you - One mailed Jan 4, and the other the 7th. The last of last week I seemed to be remarkably well - indeed I felt perfectly well only for weakness. But I suppose I undertook to do too much & this week I have felt tired a good deal of the time day times feeling better towards night and till after breakfast in the morning. I have some palpitation after eating especially but sitting down and doing nothing seemed to stop it - so I laid it to weakness, and have taken nothing so far. My appetite is pretty good for some kinds of food - I am inclined to eat too much particularly as I feel the need of something to build me up. I do not know whether I can get the Extracts of Malt or Coca here, but I will send down to day to see. I am not discouraged - think I will get along - but I seem to gain very slowly. The weather has been very cold here - but now it is quite pleasant - beautiful sunshine and mild South wind. It is cold enough nights to keep the ground covered with snow, and so far to prevent much thawing.

You do not write about your own health, are you pretty well? I suppose you find the weather in New York a good deal milder than on the Steuben hills. Do you intend to return to New York to open an office again. I presume you feel the need of a good long rest. Do you ever hear any of the celebrated men, the great preachers, or the great lectures. If I could hear, and if I were in New York, I should want to hear the men whose reputation reaches across the continent - the good men, nature's noblemen
"There is naught better than to be
With noble souls in company."
I would like to hear scientific men expound nature's laws - those who are to-day making new discoveries, and wrenching nature's secrets from her - or finding out - sometimes blind to the Great First Cause - the wonderful works of Him who is perfect in wisdom. Another word about myself. I have movements of the bowels every day. There seems to be a constriction or sluggishness about the lower bowels causing straining. When I get quite tired it affects that function. I close with love from your brother John R Everett

Could you by dropping a line to the Bible Society get this motto. I was very much struck by reading it this morning. Ps.33:6, "By the word of the Lord were the heavens made, and all the rest of them by the breath of his mouth."
I hid one of those papers of Sulphur for instance in two thirds of a cup of water and take two teaspoonsful every two hours. Is that right?

Osawatomie, Jan. 16, 1884. Dear Sister Mary
I received yours of Jan 10. yesterday morning. At the same time I got a bottle of Trommer {?} Extract of malt, of which I took three tablespoons yesterday according to directions. The Beatty Fluid Extract of Coca they did not have in Oswawatomie but had Park, Davis & Co. I had a chance to send to Paola, and got yesterday afternoon in a small Druggist's bottle something marked "Fluid Extract of Cocoa," "Dose from one to three teaspoonsful". I did not see the man I sent by. It looks on turning out in a teaspoon a little turbid, dark and purplish, and tastes aromatic. I took two doses, less than a teaspoonful, also Lactopeptine after meals. and as I thought from your description that Phosphorus was the proper thing, I took twice of that. At bedtime I had a passage of the bowels and small passages twice in the night. I shall not take ny of this Coca today. What is the effects designed from it? I thank you very much for kindly sending the different medicines (Homeo.) For what do you give Aconite, and for what Rhus? I know some uses of both. I am feeling better than I did last week - not so

tired. My appetite is good if I get what I like. I eat oysters, graham pudding, graham bread, some tomato sauce, soda crackers, and any sauce I can get. I am about out now. I have no eggs, and do not crave them. 

    Mr. Bullock was sick yesterday and has not been over yesterday nor today. He has turns of sick headache besides he complained of pain in walking in the inside muscles of his thighs. I do not think there is any thing the matter with my lungs. I cough occasionally a a loose cough -- and generally bring up some phleghm. I do not have that bad feeling in the forenoons I wrote before about. But I feel the best after about 4 or 5 oclock in the afternoon till after breakfast. I sit up most of the day. But yesterday and Sunday I laid down a good deal, and it did me good.  
    I have I believe answered all your questions. I think I am getting along pretty well-- but pretty slowly I am not careful about exposing myself -- particularly so. Osawatomie, Jan. 19, 1884.
Dear Sister Mary
Since I wrote you last Mr Bullock has been here, and I asked him to hear if there was anything wrong about my lungs. He said he was used to trying that. He found a wheezing in the right but none in the left lung. I have taken a little cold, and yesterday he could hear it in his chair three or four feet off. I thought I would mention this, although I do not attach much importance to it. I took one dose (1/2 teaspoonful) of the Ex coca yesterday, and one the day before. It seems to quicken the action of the bowels. Day before yesterday I took the Phosphorous three times. Yesterday omitted it. Today I shall take it again. I am getting a little more strength, but not to boast of much. Please excuse this short note, as I want to write a line to Steuben, and I just found out I had a chance to send to the mail.
With love your brother.

Dear Sister Mary,

She had been washing and the pain took her when she was hanging the clothes out. I told him perhaps Aconite might help her, as she had a cold. He told me this morning that it had helped

her cold, and her ear was better and running a little. He inquired of me if I knew if one could get a can of Homeopathic medicines and what they would cost. I told him I did not know any thing about it. Perhaps you could answer this. I do not know of any Homeopathic physician nearer than Parla. I have seen the advertisement of a Dr. Paulsen there. How many pellets such as you sent last would you put in two thirds of a teacup full of water?

 That motto I wrote about, I wanted to hang up as an antidote to what passes current now for the expression of scientific thought among some learned men. Sir W.  Thomson is I believe an eminent name among living English scientists. I have seen a remark attributed to him in respect to the possibility or probability of collision among the fixed stars. You know the fixed stars are all thought to be in motion - many miles a second - but their distance from us so inconceivably vast that it will take ages to make their relative positions differ. They seem to move according to no known law in every direction like meteors or comets. Sir W. Thomson likens them to ships sailing on the Atlantic Ocean, at random, if time enough is given, some two would be sure to collide. I had just been reading that when I came across this passage "By the word of the Lord the Heavens were created, and all the Host of them by the breath of his mouth." I can not believe there is no Pilot in all these vast and amazing movements in the Heavenly bodies. He that made them takes care of them. Your brother John

Osawatomie, Dec. 23, 1891.
My dear sister--

 I have learned that there are to be reduced rates to Chicago Dec 24 and 25 and Dec. 31. I intend to start Friday morning on the five o'clock train. I must make my trip as inexpensive as possible, and do not know whether it will be possible to come to Hillsdale. I have had to borrow money for this trip. I do not know what the glasses will cost. I have about $30 to start and I will have the bill for the coffin to meet--also about $50 for lumber. So I have to be as careful as possible in spending. I would like very much to come see you and our cousins but I am afraid you cannot expect me. Cousin Mary Ann gave me a very kind invitation to come there when in Chicago. Her Aunt has been there, and it was last Monday evening I received a letter from her saying her Aunt had left, and her only spare room which we have occupied

before was vacant. I have not had time to learn whether she would be at home Saturday, but I am going to risk it. I think she knew I wanted to come in the Holidays if fares were reduced. We are all well, and are having pleasant weather. Had a letter from John Eddie Monday. He had commenced his work for the Normal school, and thought he would like it. I have had the clock which was in your room repaired. It is on the red cupboard. I have heard it strike twice. I do not often with my right ear when in bed it strike at all. Osawatomie, Apr. 13. 1892.
Dear, sister Mary
Today Robert goes down with butter, and so we can get to the mail. Yours of Apr. 6 was received Saturday. I have not much to write. Nothing unusual has occurred to us. We have had two very heavy wind storms every since Eddy left, but they did us no harm. In town a few rods of plank side walk were blown about, but little harm done. We have had a good deal of rainy weather, so that we have not done much plowing yet. It rained last night. Robert planted early potatoes the last of last week. Since then we have had two rains. My health does not very much. I feel well, but do not get strong. I have taken the sulphur once or twice a day. But I have nothing to complain of. I sleep pretty well. I seem to want to make up for lost time in reading. I would like to know how you are. Do you get much time to read? It does not seem as if I can tire of reading. But

I wish I could remember a little better. I suppose you have seen Eddie by this time. I hope he will succeed in finding a place where he may be useful. I feel quite lost without Eddie.
But I have good friends close by me. I hope to hear from you again soon. With love to all from your affectionate brother
John R Everett

Osawatomie Apr 19, 1893.
My dear Sister
I received Mary card the last time I was in town. Those storms of wind about the 11th of this month did not trouble us at Osawatomie. We had heavy wind here but nothing unusual. At Parker 8 miles South West of here they had a tornado which blowed down and unroofed a good many houses. One church was blown to pieces. Wgom. Chestnut's store was unroofed, and goods damaged by the rain. I mention him because Mary knows him. The tornado originated about 7 miles South West of town. Such violent winds go in streaks, and seem to be limited to small strips of country. It is remarkable

that so few fatal accidents occur. One shoulder dislocated is the only notable hurt reported at Parker. Like lightening the stroke is in one place, and not over a large country And usually the first telegraphic report is exaggerated. We had a very heavy rain and hail storm here last night. It seldom rains so hard. It rained about an hour and a half. Yesterday we even plowing. Robert went out after the rain and heard the branch roar and found that short rain had raised the branch so as to swim ahorse, with the water up into the cow lot. Then another storm came up in the night, and it has been raining all morning. Previously the weather has been very nice. We had one frost last week hard enough for a little

ice in the water barrel. The peach trees were blossomed full - but scattering buds are not yet blown out. We are all well. Lewis knee was almost well when your medicine came. We thank you for sending all the same. I am gaining strength but slowly. We sold 17 hots last week. By taking a little pains to get to the Bank in proper hours, I am send you money now anytime. If it suits your convenience, let me know. Are you going to Chicago to the Fair? I close now with love to you both, and to all. I had a letter from Eddie last week They were well. From your brother John R Everett

Osawatomie Sept. 28, 1893. Dear sister Mary 
I was glad to get yours of the 18th last Saturday. I was hindered writing yesterday as we went down (unexpectedly to me) in the morning instead of afternoon. I am afraid you are pretty lonely, having that large house all to yourself. But pleasant memories cling to the old house, and even if you see ghosts they can not be bad spirits. How long do you intend to stay? Robert seemed to think it might be a good plan to take your stove if you incline to. Have some one pack it that understands it. Have it firmly fastened so it can not move in the box.

wrap the covers and everything loose in papers or old cloths and make them so they can not move. It seems to me the rate is moderate I think I paid five dollars a hundred when I came to Kansas. Robert thinks if I was a hard drinker I could get liquor in town So there is no great gain without some small loss. Bro. Edward writes that he is going to Chicago with Robbin this week. Carroll has been. He found Chicago almost a bigger wonder than the fair. The bank is open again. If you want money write.

Osawatomie June 12 1895.
Dear Sister Mary, One thing I forgot yesterday when writing. Do not send the feather bed. You know I rarely sleep on feathers. John Eddie just told me his goods have come. He is going to take a house in town. Ella is a little better. I write this in the P.O. so it may go out today. I am anxious to build as soon as I can. I think of building first an El 12 x 16 so as to get some shelter. I am hiring any hands boarded, 10 cents a meal. The man that boarded them lived in the Robinson house. But Robinson has come back, and he is going to move into my old corn crib. I have another good corn crib and hog pen combined that will hold 1800 bushels. I am very anxious to get shelter enough to take care of the milk. We have had beautiful rains, falling slow and not washing. Your brother, hoping to hear soon, John

Osawatomie July 10, 1897 Dear Sister Mary
Your interesting and welcome letter mailed 3 p.m. July 6 reached here 1 p.m. the 8th. I was interested in all you wrote and will prize the things you sent more for knowing what you have written. I have time to write but little now. I am waiting for Eddie (7 a.m.) to go up to the farm. I go up every day. I feel a great deal better to work some. My health is improving much faster since I have been able to exercise more. Walking for exercise is less satisfactory than when I could see better. But improvement now is marked. especially noticable [sic] in improved digestion. I suppose the same rule will not work for everyone - even every one that is seventy five years old. If you have not already done it do not say any thing to cousin Mary about the overcoat. It will be unpleasant both to you and me. But I do not feel it at all degrading to try to borrow money of those who have a superfluity, for there is property enough here to make it good. I have not done any thing yet towards building but must. I can not build any thing sufficiently comfortable or large for Eddie's family and furniture. Eddie

does not like to give up his work any more than I like to have my farm ruined by winter. I do not know of any opening to sell. To settle down and do nothing or something distasteful is not in me. When the time comes I shall know it, never fear. The old horse, if he had a voice, could tell his master when the time had come for him to stop whipping him to make him keep up the old willing pace. If one is able to work there is a solid satisfaction in eating the crust and drinking the milk earned by your own labor. Of course it is a good thing that some have money to lend and very few but would like to be in that case. But it is a sort of comfort to be with the majority and be able to look around and say "These are my brothers." Eddie has had an invitation to go next Sunday to preach as a candidate in Oneida, Nemaha county this state and intends to go next Sunday. The baby has had a bad time with his bowels. He seems to be feeling better yesterday and today - although they do not say his diarrhea is better. He is cutting his eye teeth. With love to you both Your brother John R Everett

Dear Father
You will get Kansas news much better from the N.Y. papers than I can give them. Indeed we have to wait till the "Tribune" comes to get reliable accounts from other parts of the territory. There are various stories circulating now, some very alarming, about the conditions of things here. The inhabitants in our settlement here are utterly opposed to bloodshed and anarchy, and will not take up arms unless in strict self defense. Five slave state men were killed last Saturday night up the Pottawatomie. This was most deeply deplored and condemned by the entire community here. They held a meeting and condemned it in the strongest language, and resolved to do what they could to bring the offenders to justice. In our entire community I do not know of one who is professionally in

favor of a slave state. We have appointed a committee of safety to look after the defense (if necessary) of the settlement, while each settler goes quietly about his usual business. In my judgment all the present serious trouble has arisen from the Southern thieves (miscalled emigrants) who have come from the far South this spring. From the accounts we hear from all quarters a more miserable set of men could not have been picked up. Without any means to procure tomorrow's bread, the Missourians chose to set them to plundering their neighbors rather than support them themselves. We are told they plundered every house in Lawrence, and left even women without changes of underclothing. We hear of some men there rendered desperate, who are giving them something to do, so that may keep them away from us.

When you came home, I was very anxious to get a letter from you if it was only to see your hand writing. I suppose you feel anxious to hear from home, as we both did before I started from Grafenberg [?]. And although I have nothing particular to say of myself, and do not feel any special attack of the writing distemper, still I take my pen in hand on the principle of doing as I would be done by. I called on Uncle Hughes [?] family and Aunt Sarah in passing through York Mills. They were all well. The handkerchief that come around your pants belongs to Cousin William. It was sent by mistake. Sent it back the first opportunity. Elizabeth and June and Mr Butter were in usual health. They were much surprised to see me. They thought I looked better, but thinner. There was quite a fire in Whitesboro Wednesday morning about 11 o'[clock. Clapp's Tavern was burnt down. I went up to see what was going on, and accidentally got to the side of [?] Green in the line of water carriers. He is full of water-cure, inquired for my health and whereabouts. I told him I was staying at Grafenberg. He said I looked as if I had been practicing the hunger cure. Mr. Green has been curing a man of the name of Wilson of fever and ague

in his house - the wet sheet for the fever and tepid half baths for the chills. I got home by the accommodation about 1/2 past 8 Wednesday night. I was the last child they expected to see. Lewis does not look very well. Mother's leg is pretty bad now. She tried the leg bath this morning - the water was not quite cold. It seemed to ease it for some time. Sarah is about as usual. The rest are pretty well. They have got the first forms worked off and about six pages set on the last form. I saw Green to day in the village. He is not nearly as well as he was when you saw him. He has been troubled with diarrhea for about a fortnight, and it has weakened him a good deal. He says he is coming on to Graffenberg as soon as he gets strong enough. He talked of coming next week. Yeomans is laid up with his rheumatic gout. He says he is coming on there in July. I do not feel as well since I came home. My boils trouble me some. I took a pack and two sitz baths yesterday; the same today. Suffer some from the hunger disease (was going to say "cure'). Saw Rees Roberts the night I came home. "How do you do Mr. Roberts?" said I. "I have been better for the last month," said he, "I live on rye and indian bread." Old Mrs. James died yesterday - funeral tomorrow. Father Penny died very suddenly in York Mills last Sunday. He was in Meeting Sunday evening. He was called on to speak. Said he had not intended to speak but perhaps it was his last opportunity. He said if he could choose his place to die it would be in the altar after making

after remarks he sat down in the altar, his head declined on one side, he gave a groan, and his spirit departed! sissy is sitting by me reading the Bible. The chapters for today are Romans 11, 12, 13. I think now of coming back next Monday or Tuesday. Write home, without waiting for me, for they will be very glad to hear from you. anna and Mary wrote to you in the beginning of the week. Father and Mother and May (a whole bunch of it) and Sarah (with all her heart) and Anna and Sissy and all send their love to you. So I must close this rambling letter from your affectionate brother. So the news we got in the Cen. was very acceptable. We had a chance to send to Lawrence next day to have our letters forwarded from there. Have not yet got them. Got your letter, dated April 30, last Thursday evening. Were very glad to hear from you. I presume you will have seen the letter we wrote to Robert by Mr Knox. I have not much news to send. Emigrants continue to crowd into the country. The man who assumes the chief management in this settlement, Mr Brown, is not at all truthful. So most of those who come here now go away again. In fact the wood about here is all taken about, or covered by claims in some way. There are many false claims however, when one man tries to hold more than his share. Those who get on to such claims, although their legal right is perfect, generally have some trouble with them. We are having a little trouble with ours. The Justice of the Peace here assures us that our right under the preemption law is indisputable, and that we shall be protected in our rights. Still we may be defrauded. Osawatomie June 19, 1856
Dear Father, 
Yours and Robert's of June 4 received. Very glad to hear Robert is so well. I sent last week for 2 more Tribunes and 4 more 3 week ago with the money in both cases ($6.00) If not received let me know. The P.U. saw me enclose the money and Marley U. will bear the loss. The pie plants Lewis sent, & of them?, are growing nicely. Hope you will not lose so much on your one hand as you were afraid at first. Dear father and Robert, I cannot agree with your reasonings on the peace question. The same principle which would constrain us & leave Kansas for the sake of peace would carry slavery triumphant over the whole country. Would you leave your homes because the slaveholders wished to make

New York a Slave State? Senator Loombs says he will yet call the roll of his slavs in the shadow of Bunker Hill Monument. Shall the "solid men" of Boston" there immediately leave when they hear the clank of the slave {{unclear]] and the crack of the overseers whip, lest they be obliged to fight for their principles? For all free state men to leave now would be to surrender Kansas inevitably to slavery. This we cannot do. We would thus commit a crime against God and humanity which a thousand lifetimes would not suffice to expiate. I think liberty for the teeming population which is yet destined to fill this middle land of our country would be cheaply purchased by the blood of every settler now on it. But

this sacrifice is not necessary. Compare the intelligent intellectual free child with the ignorant animal slave child, the virtuous free maiden with the unutterable woe that hangs over the slave girl, a "man created in the image of God," with a slave--and say whether we should tamely submit to suffer this land to be polluted by the sum of all villainies.
But do not suppose we are going to enlist on an indiscriminate crusade, to take up arms for he mere sake of hitting somebody. We mean (the people generally to stay here, to avoid collision if possible, if attacked of course to defend ourselves if we can. Such an attitude will keep assailants off. But I think we

will be let alone. We are inclined about here to be very peaceable. Meanwhile do everything to unite all friends of justice in the next election for free Kansas. This is the point assailed. Concentrate all your forces upon it. Other points may be very important in their time but this is the point to gain now. Lose here and the enemy have turned? the lines, and can take the other defences one by one. I wish all our old Liberty friends could perceive this. We are quite well. The U.S. troops are still here. Company D of the Cavalry. Dear Robert, write us again as soon as you can. Affectionately, John

Owatomie, Feb. 27 '56
Dear Father
The mail did not go out last week, and probably will not this, on account of high water. Consequently we have had no mail this week, and will not have till the streams fall enough to be fordable. I mailed a letter last week which perhaps you will get at the same time as this. I will write as I think of anything, and try to get it in before the mail goes out again. 
Mother inquires in her letter (Jan 11) what the box cost us. It was $4.15's namely $1.30 in St. Louis 1.50 on river .50 in Kansas .85 Kansas there
The river was unusually low and the price high in proportion. 
Thursday morning, March 7--We received yours of Feb. 15 & Sissy's of Feb 6 day before yesterday -- with the $19 draft enclosed. Were very glad to hear that Robert was so much better. Would like to know (when the list is completed) how much paper you wet? for Cenhadwn, and how many you are sending out this year. Glad to hear the list is increasing a little. Could you send one or two (or 3 or 4) currant cuttings (last year's growth from my bushes) in a newspaper or two and a Fastolff Raspberry root in another? 
[[Note on side}} We pass the drafts to the merchants here without discount, but I have to wait a few days for the cash that they may not layout of their money till they can turn them.

(I think it will injure them to be frozen - off the ground.) The box came to hand so late, we could not set out those roots and cuttings last fall, and I am afraid they are dead. It begins to look a little springlike here - about like your April - frosty nights and pleasant days. We have sold the stove we bought last fall to a carpenter who will help fix up our house. We were only obliged to sacrifice a little over a dollar on it. Sarah's health does not improve much. She is taking some strengthening medicine from a doctor. It seems to help her a little, but not a great deal. We have kept a girl now 3 weeks. She is going home today. We pay $1.50 a week. Good girls are scarce.
The people's Legislature met at Topeka last Tuesday. It may be that there will be a collision between them and the Missouri border ruffian Legislature. We are fortunate in our people's Governor, Charles Robinson, an antislavery man from the East. He will not [?] a job of principle, but he proved himself as the leader of the people's forces in the Lawrence War of Independence a man of great moderation and prudence, and it was probably owing to him that no more blood was spilt there. 
Franky is waiting. I read something I wrote, to his mother, and Franky started up and read his letter. Is shame to him to read, " That boy naughty, papa whip him!"

The president's proclamation about Kansas received here, especially among Western men with contempt and scorn. It will not be easy for Frank Pierce to conquer us in the interest of Missouri, especially with so strong a feeling in the popular branch of Congress in our favor, and also among the masses of the people in the North.
I have thought for some time that it would not be best for us to get a team this spring. If I can get one horse cheap, and you can help one, I shall do it. I do not know what help I shall need, because I do not know what it will cost. I shall not get a high-priced animal. It is costing us a good deal to have now, especially account of Sarah's continued illness. If we can get through this hard time, and get our health, I am not afraid but that we can get along here, and pay our debts. I think I can get a school with pretty fair ways next winter, and perhaps but not likely this summer.
No more now. Love to all at home John.

Osawatomie, July 17, 1836
Dear Father
There is considerable sickness about here now, especially among the newcomers. We hear that there is a great deal of sickness among the Southerners. Our health continues quite good. We have had very dry weather. Scarcely any rain now for nearly five weeks. We have heard of no fresh disturbances, although we still mourn over our leaders in prison or driven from the territory, and liberty completely stricken down. There is no people on the globe who have less to say in the conduct of their public affairs than the people of Kansas. This is no government of the people, but a government forced upon us by a mob of the vilest rabble of our neighboring state, enforced now alas by U.S. bayonets. We have had to submit to degrading insult, to having our house, burnt to the excesses of mob violence - women ravished, men beaten to death and shot in cold blood, men hung because their speech [?] [?] them to have come from the free hills of New England and their murderers repeating in mockery their prayers to heaven while the dead yet hung on the tree. We have seen our best men, our peacefully appointed Legislators, who had assembled to try to devise some relief, dispessed [?] at the point of the sabre. These things hang like the heaviest weight upon our spirits. We feel

the galling yoke of the oppressor. The [?] enters our souls. We hoped this State would be free for all as is the air of heaven, and now we are slaves. If you could feel this as we feel it you would readily excuse those who have taken up arms to "do or die" for liberty. You would drop a tear over even their excesses, and your pity would wipe out your blame. But while the whole power of the federal government Executive, judiciary and military is against us, we are devotedly attached to the general government and to the Union. We would do nought against it. But the territorial Legislature and its laws, we scorn despise and in no wise bow to. That Legislature is the representation of the lowest of the low in this town, but not ours. Now we look to the North. Will they tamely see the liberty of their own white brethren trampled down? Oh, if justice could every where predominate, and liberty take rank of party in the minds of all the people, we would have no fears. 
Remember me kindly to John D Griffiths & Gwen, Mary H. Jones boys, J.W. Roberts & family, Thomas Jones (store) and a hundred others , I could name, and tell them all to do what they can for freedom in Kansas.
With much love
Your son John

Osawatomie, Oct. 11, 1877.
My dear son
I received yours of Oct. 2, day before yesterday. I was very glad to get your letter. I was feeling very lonely and had been longing for a letter so long, I began to get discouraged. I think you are having a very good chance for schooling - much better than you could have here. I used to be very fond of Algebra and Arithmetic and liked Grammar. What history are you studying? I never studied Geology at school, but it is a subject of inquiry I am much interested in. I would like to study it practically with an intelligent teacher - go to the rocks and interrogate nature. Not many months ago a variety of rock was discovered a few miles from here, by

man or two brothers engaged in the marble business. They are old settlers - boys here twenty years ao. They had a stone threshold of the rock, and found by the constant wear of feet, that it was capable of a high polish. Under the microscope it seems composed entirely of minute shells, one I noticed a trilobite, but microscopic, the shells floating apparent by in some unclear so transparent that you can see part of the outline of the shells below the surface. The stone-cutter, who excavated some rock for them, showed me the stone - a specimen- under a prospecting glass, magnifying 40 or fifty diameters he thought. I was much interested in it, and thought how much undiscovered wealth lies around us, if we had eyes to see it. The Earth is our home, and a pretty good one, - the Lord said "very good;" but I fear we are very much strangers in it. This stone is being

used now for grave stores or monuments. It was submitted to a competent geologist at a school of Natural History in Atchison, (85m. north in this state) and he called it a variety of marble _ (my informant said Corlean or Corneal)
I have over fifty acres in cultivation, 160 fenced. I have two hired boys working . I paid them $16 a month this summer. Last winter for 2 or 3 months I had two  young men working for their brand _ one going to school. I do not think I find farming very profitable as I can not work enough out of doors myself.
